item.title: Molly add a quote by Sharon Olds
item.description: "I see them standing at the formal gates of their colleges, I see my father strolling out under the ochre sandstone arch, the red tiles glinting like bent plates of blood behind his head, I see my mother with a few light books at her hip standing at the pillar made of tiny bricks with the wrought-iron gate still open behind her, its sword-tips black in the May air, they are about to graduate, they are about to get married, they are kids, they are dumb, all they know is they are innocent, they would never hurt anybody. I want to go up to them and say Stop, don't do it--she's the wrong woman, he's the wrong man, you are going to do things you cannot imagine you would ever do, you are going to do bad things to children, you are going to suffer in ways you never heard of, you are going to want to die. I want to go up to them there in the late May sunlight and say it, her hungry pretty blank face turning to me, her pitiful beautiful untouched body, his arrogant handsome blind face turning to me, his pitiful beautiful untouched body, but I don't do it. I want to live. I take them up like the male and female paper dolls and bang them together at the hips like chips of flint as if to strike sparks from them, I say Do what you are going to do, and I will tell about it" -- Sharon Olds

item.title: Molly add a quote by Czeslaw Milosz
item.description: "The purpose of poetry is to remind us how difficult it is to remain just one person, for our house is open, there are no keys in the doors, and invisible guests come in and out at will." -- Czeslaw Milosz

item.title: Molly add a quote by Roland Barthes
item.description: "Language is a skin: I rub my language against the other. It is as if I had words instead of fingers, or fingers at the tip of my words. My language trembles with desire." -- Roland Barthes

item.title: Molly add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "The man who does not read has no advantage over the man who cannot read." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Molly add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "Substitute 'damn' every time you're inclined to write 'very;' your editor will delete it and the writing will be just as it should be." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Molly add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "In a good bookroom you feel in some mysterious way that you are absorbing the wisdom contained in all the books through your skin, without even opening them." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Molly add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "The difference between the right word and the almost right word is the difference between lightning and a lightning bug." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Molly add a quote by Pablo Neruda
item.description: "I love you without knowing how, or when, or from where. I love you simply, without problems or pride: I love you in this way because I do not know any other way of loving but this, in which there is no I or you, so intimate that your hand upon my chest is my hand, so intimate that when I fall asleep your eyes close." -- Pablo Neruda

item.title: Molly add a quote by Anne Morrow Lindbergh
item.description: "Security in a relationship lies neither in looking back to what it was in nostalgia, nor forward to what it might be in dread or anticipation, but living in the present relationship and accepting it as it is now." -- Anne Morrow Lindbergh

item.title: Molly add a quote by Susan Howe
item.description:
"we that were wood when that wide wood was
in a physical Universe playing with
words
bark be my limbs my hair be leaf Bride be my bow my lyre my quiver " -- Susan Howe

item.title: Molly add a quote by Lorrie Moore
item.description: "Pleasantness was the machismo of the Midwest. There was something athletic about it. You flexed your face into a smile and let it hover there like the dare of a cat." -- Lorrie Moore

item.title: Molly add a quote by Gertrude Stein
item.description: "There is no such thing as repetition. Only insistance. " -- Gertrude Stein

item.title: Molly add a quote by Wallace Stevens
item.description: "One must read poetry with one's nerves." -- Wallace Stevens

item.title: Molly add a quote by Franz Kafka
item.description: "A book must be the axe for the frozen sea within us." -- Franz Kafka

item.title: Molly add a quote by Rita Dove
item.description: "If we’re going to solve the problems of the world, we have to learn how to talk to one another. Poetry is the language at its essence. It’s the bones and the skeleton of the language. It teaches you, if nothing else, how to choose your words." -- Rita Dove

item.title: Molly add a quote by Richard Powers
item.description: "Evil is the refusal to see one's self in others." -- Richard Powers

item.title: Molly add a quote by Richard Powers
item.description: "Librarian is a service occupation. Gas station attendant of the mind." -- Richard Powers

item.title: Molly add a quote by Cate Marvin
item.description: "I am like a table that eats its own legs off because it’s fallen in love with the floor." -- Cate Marvin

item.title: Molly add a quote by Gretel Ehrlich
item.description: "Autumn teaches us that fruition is also death; that ripeness is a form of decay. The willows, having stood for so long near water, begin to rust. Leaves are verbs that conjugate the seasons." -- Gretel Ehrlich

item.title: Molly add a quote by Robert Bly
item.description: "BAD PEOPLE A man told me once that all the bad people Were needed. Maybe not all, but your fingernails You need; they are really claws, and we know Claws. The sharks—what about them? They make other fish swim faster. The hard-faced men In black coats who chase you for hours In dreams—that’s the only way to get you To the shore. Sometimes those hard women Who abandon you get you to say, “You.” A lazy part of us is like a tumbleweed. It doesn’t move on its own. Sometimes it takes A lot of Depression to get tumbleweeds moving. Then they blow across three or four States. This man told me that things work together. Bad handwriting sometimes leads to new ideas; And a careless god—who refuses to let people Eat from the Tree of Knowledge—can lead To books, and eventually to us. We write Poems with lies in them, but they help a little." -- Robert Bly

item.title: Molly add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "There was a star riding through clouds one night, & I said to the star, 'Consume me'." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Molly add a quote by Susan Griffin
item.description: "The mind can forget what the body, defined by each breath, subject to the heart beating, does not." -- Susan Griffin

item.title: Molly add a quote by Leo Tolstoy
item.description: "He stepped down, trying not to look long at her, as if she were the sun, yet he saw her, like the sun, even without looking." -- Leo Tolstoy

item.title: Molly add a quote by E. L. Doctorow
item.description: "I am led to the proposition that there is no fiction or nonfiction as we commonly understand the distinction: there is only narrative." -- E. L. Doctorow

item.title: Molly add a quote by Susan Sontag
item.description: "My library is an archive of longings." -- Susan Sontag

item.title: Molly add a quote by Rollo May
item.description: "What genuine painters do is to reveal the underlying psychological and spiritual conditions of their relationship to their world; thus in the works of a great painter we have a reflection of the emotional and spiritual condition of human beings in that period of history. If you wish to understand the psychological and spiritual temper of any historical period, you can do no better than to look long and searchingly at its art. For in the art the underlying spiritual meaning of the period is expressed directly in symbols. This is not because artists are didactic or set out to teach or to make propaganda; to the extend that they do, their power of expression is broken; their direct relations to the inarticulate, or, if you will, 'unconscious' levels of the culture is destroyed. They have the power to reveal the underlying meaning of any period precisely because the essence of art is the powerful and alive encounter between the artist and his or her world." (pg 52)" -- Rollo May

item.title: Molly add a quote by Alice Walker
item.description: "The most common way people give up their power is by thinking they don't have any." -- Alice Walker
